title: Current - charge during 0 to 3 s versus 3 s to 4 s

content.question: Starting at time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, a section of wire has an electric current, always directed toward the right in the wire section. The current is <math alttext="2 amperes" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> during the time interval <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than 3 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math> and <math alttext="3 amperes" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> during the time interval <math alttext="3 seconds less than or equal to t, less than 4 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>4</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math>. During which time interval does more charge pass through a cross section of the wire, and why is the charge greater for that interval?

choices.label: <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than 3 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math>, because this is the longer of the two time intervals.

<math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than 3 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math>, because the product of the current and the time interval is greater.

<math alttext="3 seconds less than or equal to t, less than 4 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>4</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math>, because this is the later of the two time intervals.

<math alttext="3 seconds less than or equal to t, less than 4 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>4</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math>, because the current is greater in this time interval.

content.answer: <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than 3 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math>, because the product of the current and the time interval is greater.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
